bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Howard A. Kelly, April 28, 1927

div1.p: Kean discusses the roles of Reed, Carroll, and Noguchi, in investigating yellow fever. Kean supports Wood's assessment that Reed was the guiding and controlling mind behind the experiments, and the others were mere assistants. Kean states that new evidence shows Noguchi never cultivated the yellow fever organism.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Howard A. Kelly, April 28, 1927
div1.opener:
from J. R. Kean
28 April, 1927.
Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
1406 Eutaw Place,
Baltimore, Maryland.
My dear Dr. Kelly:
div1.p:
I am just back from a sojourn at Walter Reed
where Keller has been putting some repairs on my abdominal
wall and I find your little note to Garrison (which I en-
close) on my desk. I knew Dr. Porter very well as I was
stationed for more than two years in Key West just before
the Spanish War and we have had a rather active correspon-
dence within the last year which touched on the yellow
fever matter and was suggested by his sending me his little
autobiographical sketch called “Looking backward over fifty
years of health work in Florida”. It appeared in the
Florida Medical Society between July, 1925 and January,
1926.

Dr. Porter makes no claim in this sketch or in
any of his correspondence that I have seen to have contri-
buted anything towards the discovery that yellow fever was
transmitted by mosquitoes. He gave credit to Reed, where
it belongs, on all occasions. Colonel Garrison has just
been talking to me about some suggestions made by Dr. Hemme-
ter in his book that Major James Carroll deserves more credit
than is usually given him in this matter. I was, as you
know, the disbursing officer of the Commission and was in
a position to have first hand knowledge about the whole work
and I know that General Leonard Wood stated the facts in the
case with his customary clearness and accuracy when he said
that he was in a position to know and he knew that in this
work Reed was the guiding and controlling mind and that the
others were assistants merely.

I showed this in a review which I was requested
by the publishers to write of the last edition of your book,
Walter Reed and Yellow Fever. This review was never pub-
lished and the Editor wrote me that it had been lost. By
the way, I think when you get out another edition you will
have to leave out Noguchi's claim to be one of the Big Four
in yellow fever discoveries. Major Gallonder tells me that
the evidence is [unclear] about complete that Noguchi has been
- 2 -
working with the spirochete of Weil's Disease and has
not actually cultivated yellow fever organism at all.
This explains something which I could never understand
which was that Noguchi could cultivate the organism in
laboratory animals whereas the experiments of Reed's
Board to do so were not successful.
div1.closer:
With best wishes, I am
Very sincerely yours, J. R. KEAN Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired
Editor.
JRK/W
